docTitle.titlePart:
Electrochemical studies of the interaction of sulfadiazine with DNA on a multi-walled carbon nanotube modified glassy carbon
electrode

byline.docAuthor: Ayemeh Bagheri Hashkavayi, Lida Fotouhi*, Majid M. Heravi

byline.affiliation: Department of Chemistry, School of Science, Alzahra University.

front.div:
Interaction of sulfadiazine (SD) with double-stranded calf thymuse DNA both in solution and DNA immobilized on the multi-walled
carbon nanotube modified glassy carbon electrode (MWCNT-GCE) were investigated by cyclic voltammetry, chrono coulometery and
UV-Vis spectroscopy. The binding of SD with DNA, when analyzed in terms of the cooperative Hill model, yields the binding constant,
and a Hill coefficient in Britton-Robinson (B-R) buffer solution, pH =6.5. The diffusion coefficient of SD-DNA was also estimated using
chronocoulometery. Kinetic parameters such as the electron transfer coefficient between SD and modified electrode, , and
heterogeneous rate constant, ks, were determined according to the procedure of Laviron [1]. The pH of buffer affects the formation of
complex SD-DNA, hence, pH were optimized. The effect of the injected volume of MWCNT composite film was also investigated. In
the presence of DNA, oxidation peak current of SD decreases which indicates the interaction of SD with DNA. The Hill coefficient , m,
can be obtained from the slope of the equation as 2.05, which proves the binding ratio of DNA:SD complex is 1:2. Morever, the value of
Ka was calculated to be 3.1×10
7 M
-1 . By the plot of the oxidation-wave potential against the pH-value for SD at MWCNT-GCE-DNA,
three defined breaks at corresponding to the apparently pKa values, 1.9, 4.2 and 7.2 were obtained. The results of UV-Vis absorption
studies also indicate that the DNA retains its double-helical structure in the mixed solution, confirming the dominance of electrostatic
interactions [2]. Electron transfer coefficient between SD and modified electrode, and heterogeneous rate constant, were obtained 1.27
and 420.4 s
-1 respectively. From the Cottrell equation, diffusion coefficient of DNA bond drug was obtained D=9.49×10
-6 cm
2 s
-1 .
